content: Europa Series 2 (Federal) Type 65: The new Series 2 Europa, which was produced under the Type 54 Lotus designation, was launched in 1968 and, the following year, was sold for the very first time in the UK. There was, however, another significant market for Lotus. Colin Chapman’s marque was well known in the United States, mainly through racing exploits and particularly because of its Indianapolis successes. Jay Chamberlain had been an enthusiastic agent for Lotus in the USA, supplying Sevens and Elites up until 1961, when he went bankrupt after parts supply difficulties from Britain. He was succeeded by a variety of regional importers. Some of these managed to bring in a handful of Series 1 Europas, but in standard form they were definitely not to Federal-specification, requiring new headlamp bowls to raise them to the required minimum height. However, such sales did prove that there was a market for the Europa in the United States. The peculiar requirements of Federal laws forced many changes on manufacturers and Lotus evidently felt that the extent of the modifications it had to make justified a whole new type number for the American specification Europa. It was duly allotted Type number 65.

It was duly allotted Type number 65. The single most important difference between the American and European cars was the fitment of a larger 1565cc Renault engine taken from the 16TS, an up-market version of the Renault R16 launched in 1968. Because the 1470cc engine was modified especially for Lotus, it did not qualify under Federal emissions regulations. However, the larger engine did because it was left exactly as it came from Renault. Federal equipment – including a catch tank and charcoal canister – overcame any problems with emissions. The larger engine still produced 80bhp at 6000rpm, and so performance was very similar. In Federal form, the Europa S2 had a revised bodyshell to suit a variety of minor modifications, the most obvious being the raised front wing and headlamp profile, to comply with US regulations. New doors incorporated fresh internal and external locks and handles, and the wiring loom was modified to suit the fitment of brake.

The Type 70 used the same track/wheelbase ratio as the company’s 1967 Formula 1 car, Type 49B. content: A change in fuel tank regulations for 1970 forced those manufacturers keen to continue competing in Formula 2 to substantially modify their existing cars in order to accommodate new aircraft-style rubber bag fuel tanks. At Lotus, designer David Baldwin conceived a new car, in effect a redesign of the Type 59, but with a new forward monocoque attached to the rear spaceframe. Further modifications were made to the suspension, principally by the inclusion of new destruction-tested lower wishbones, and the 59’s snub-nose was replaced by a low-line wedge with an underslung intake feeding air through the radiator. A single large exhaust duct replaced the twin air-extractors featured on the older car. The new machine made its debut at the first round of the 1970 European Championship at Thruxton, appearing under the banner of Jochen Rindt Racing Limited, Rindt and his manager Bernie Ecclestone having taken control of the factory’s Formula 2 programme after Roy Winkelmann’s departure. Chassis 69-F2-4, Rindt’s own, wore the traditional dark green livery for the race alongside several private entries including Emerson Fittipaldi (69-F2-1) and Tetsu Ikuzawa (69-F2-2) from Japan. Rindt, ever the master of the formula, took pole position and won the race.

content: The light-alloy monocoque design, with its wedge nose and twin wings, reminded some observers of a hammerhead shark. Conceived by Colin Chapman and executed by Maurice Philippe, it proved to be perhaps the lightest car in Formula 1. The car's weight equalled the minimum permitted level of 530 kg, including fluids. Every aspect of the car evinced new and radical thinking. In appearance, its most visibly striking features were the side-mounted radiators, which allowed the car's designers to find an aerodynamically more efficient profile than previous cars. The gearbox from Hewland and the engine, Cosworth's 3-litre DFV, remained open to the elements. However, elsewhere, attention to aerodynamics was impeccable with flush rivets on external planes, a slim nose profile, and carefully contoured rear sections to give the best possible penetration and airflow. Throughout its five-year life, the car was most closely associated with sponsor John Player & Son, initially racing in red. Launched to the assembled press at Hethel on 6th April 1970, the Lotus Type 72, with no fewer than twenty Grand Prix victories to its name over the course of five years, established itself as one of the truly great Grand Prix cars. Car stats: Weight: 530 kg, Engine: Cosworth 3-litre DFV, Gearbox: Hewland.

Racing in the red, launched to the assembled press at Hethel on 6th April 1970, the Lotus Type 72 established itself as one of the truly great Grand Prix cars. Indeed, it could arguably claim to be the most outstanding Formula 1 car of its decade, if not of all time. Initially adorned in the white and gold of Gold Leaf Team Lotus, it soon adopted the soon-to-be world-famous black and gold livery as the very first John Player Special. The Type 72 made its debut at the 1970 Spanish Grand Prix but failed to find much success until Rindt took pole position in practice at Zandvoort. With Rindt going on to win the race itself, as well as the French, German, and British rounds in 72/R2 (Rindt also won the Monaco GP that year after reverting back to the trusty Type 49), he took the driver's title, with Team Lotus also taking the constructors' championship. Throughout the season, numerous small modifications were made, most noticeably the addition of an airbox over the injection system, an innovation soon adopted by several rival teams.

The 1970 season was overshadowed by the tragic loss of Rindt during official practice at Monza. Despite there being three races left in the season, his points total of 45 could only be surpassed by one driver, Jacky Ickx in the Ferrari. Emerson Fittipaldi was thrust into the limelight as team leader to defend Rindt's position at the top of the table. After the team missed the Canadian Grand Prix, Fittipaldi came of age at the United States Grand Prix at Watkins Glen. On race day, he drove a steady race, benefiting from the retirements of others to score his first Grand Prix win and ensure that Jochen Rindt became the sport's first and only posthumous World Champion. For the 1971 season, the Type 72 remained almost unchanged, save for a few minor modifications. The Type 72 was a milestone car in Formula 1 history.

content:
Renault’s involvement with Lotus continued, however, albeit at a lower level. In the interests of manufacturing economy, the new car continued to employ the company’s 4-speed gearbox. This was mated to a bespoke Lotus-only bellhousing which also accommodated the alternator and, onto which were mounted the inboard ends of the lower suspension links. The use of this gearbox also influenced the choice of engine, the 105bhp Lotus Twin-cam. Had the factory opted for the more powerful version, as indeed it was to do later, a rather stronger and so more costly transmission assembly would have been called for. Despite the car’s broadly similar external appearance, this was, all in all, an extensive revision to the existing model. The company clearly paid heed to the comments and constructive criticisms of the many Lotus owners and independent road testers with first-hand experience of the earlier Type 46 and who had enjoyed its racing car layout and spirited handling.

The most obvious modification was to the Europa’s characteristic rear fins which were cut down almost to the level of the rear deck. This was done in order to improve three-quarter rear vision, although it remains open to debate whether the change helped or hindered visibility.

At the same time, modified seats fixed to a lower floorpan helped the driving position, as did the new, wider footwells and a relocated pedal assembly. The upgraded interior was quite definitely more luxurious than that of previous Europas. A new chin spoiler refreshed the appearance of the front end, and two new fuel tanks increased the car's fuel capacity to 12.5 gallons. A revised gearchange linkage and improved suspension completed the package, which was attractively priced at £1,995 (including car tax) or just £1,595 if supplied in component form. Finally, the company's own 5½-inch 'Brand Lotus' light alloy wheels served to further distinguish the new car from the Types 46 and 54. This was done in a vain attempt to keep the power output of the heavily restricted Federal specification car somewhere near that of its European specification Twin-cam powered cousin. The big-valve engine in European trim was putting out close to 130 bhp, but by the time it had made the trip across the Atlantic, this had fallen to just 105 bhp. This was due mainly to the fact that the high-compression aspect of the engine was dropped for US-bound cars, changes in camshaft timing, as well as the use of Weber carburettors in place of either the side-draught 40DLHA Dellortos on the first cars built, or Strombergs on later models. The new Europa Twin-Cam formed a big part of the financial recovery of Group Lotus during 1971. With the closure of Lotus Components coming before the year was halfway through, the emphasis of Lotus was now focused on the road car production side of the business. The future for the company was looking bright. Gross profit for the first half of 1971 was a healthy £324,000.

Since the mid-1960s, Lotus had been building the successful Renault-engined version of its low-slung Type 46 sports car. Now called the Europa in all markets, it was built alongside the Elan Sprint, Elan Plus 2S, and Series 4 Seven until 1971, when it was decided to replace the mildly-tuned French engine with the company's own 1,558cc Lotus-Ford twin-cam unit. The resulting combination carried the new Type number designation of 74.

content: The big news at Team Lotus for 1972 was the announcement late in 1971 that the Type 72D variation, which had appeared part way through 1971, would be painted in a stunning new black and gold color scheme, and the cars re-named the 'John Player Specials.' This dramatic change of image for the whole team was brought about by the confirmation that John Player & Son would be continuing their long-running sponsorship of Team Lotus for a further three years, and that the entire outfit would now be known as John Player Team Lotus. Other new sponsors coming into the fold were Texaco, who took over from Shell as fuel and oils supplier, while Champion spark plugs replaced the in-house Ford brand of plugs, Autolite. The team did, however, stay with the same tire manufacturer, Firestone, for this year at least. The car shown at the Hethel launch, on a typical cold, grey December day in Norfolk, was essentially the same as the car run throughout 1971, but by the time of the secondary sponsors announcement the car sported a dramatic new 'anvil' shaped airbox and deep end plates on the rear wing.

content: In time, the car appeared in Formula 3 guise, markedly less sleek than the Type 72 but highly advanced by prevailing class standards. The basic design was originally done by Maurice Philippe, but after his departure to assist the Vels Parnelli team with their new Formula 1 car, completion was left to Martin Waide and David Baldwin. They incorporated many of the more successful features of the Type 72, including a full monocoque center section, side-mounted radiators, a complex sub-frame mounting for the front suspension, and the unitary engine/transmission/suspension assembly at the rear end. The aforementioned forward tubular sub-frame carried the rack and pinion steering and inboard brakes, as well as rising rate front suspension with fabricated double wishbones and inboard spring and damper units. The air-restricted 130bhp Novamotor-developed Lotus dohc engine and a Hewland Mark 8 gearbox formed a stressed chassis member, attached using a tubular framework, and with inboard rear brakes, the rear suspension was formed around single upper links, parallel twin lower links, twin radius arms with outboard coil-spring/damper assemblies. Conceived to complement the stunning success of its big brother, the innovative and triumphant Type 72, the Lotus Type 73 was a Formula 3 car intended to sport the same black and gold JPS livery and, it was hoped, follow its winning form. Its origins derived from a proposed Formula 2 car planned for the 1971 season but which fell victim to the closure of Lotus Racing (Lotus Components) who built the customer race cars. This attractive but perhaps overly-complex design was to fulfil its potential.

Shortly afterwards, however, Trimmer took a good second at the prestigious Formula 3 support race to the Monaco Grand Prix (despite suffering tyre overheating problems), beaten only by the highly competitive Alpine-Renault of Patrick Depailler, and that with its suspect Renault engine. In April, he took first place at Mallory Park, having placed fourth the previous month at Brands Hatch. Other notable drives for Trimmer in the Type 73 included a fifth placing at Mallory, and a sixth at the Swedish circuit Anderstorp in the early summer. Vermilio, whose car was fitted with a slightly smaller cockpit than Trimmer's, fared less well, finishing just fourth at Zandvoort and sixth at Paul Ricard. content: Around 1,580 'Twin Cam' Europas were shipped before August of 1971, at which point Lotus switched production to use the 126 bhp Big Valve engine, and the 'Europa Special' was born. Aspirated by Dellorto carburettors and offering a new Renault 5-speed (Type 365) gearbox option, it weighed in at a slightly heavier 1,631 lb. The UK magazine Motor famously tested a 'Special' to a top speed of 123 mph (198 km/h), completed 0–60 mph in 6.6 seconds, and ran the 1/4 mile in 14.9 seconds. At a time when all road tests were carried out with both a driver and passenger, the 0–60 mph time would have been well under 6 seconds minus the passenger, a phenomenal performance for the period. Introduced in September 1972, many of the first Big Valve cars were painted to capitalize on the Formula 1 World Championship title that Team Lotus had just won with John Player Special as sponsors. All built with a 5-speed gearbox, these cars were of course painted black with gold pin stripes matching the livery of the Type 72 GP cars. With a numbered badge seemingly fitted to the dashboard by dealers and customers, they became the first of several Black & Gold commemorative cars from Lotus.

content: 1973 Based around a striking but actually quite simple sheet aluminium alloy monocoque with GRP bodywork, the racing Type 74 was the work of Ralph Bellamy. Its most distinguishing feature at the car's launch was a wide, though not quite full-width, shovel-shaped nose section. The fabricated double wishbone front suspension operated inboard torsion bars and dampers, while at the rear, there was a more conventional coil spring/damper set up. The disc brakes were inboard at all four corners, and the side-mounted radiators for oil and water were fitted almost flush to the sides of the monocoque. Power came from the Lotus Type 906 alloy block, a twin overhead camshaft unit of 1,973cc and, some said, a derivation of its production engine, itself based on the cast iron General Motors/Vauxhall Victor unit that had already been extensively modified by Novamotor. By Formula 2 standards, it was a fairly large power pack, also a somewhat uncompetitive one, by the time several early reliability problems had been dealt with. Figures for its original power output are not available, but by the time early problems were resolved and the car was considered ready for competition, a rating of around 275bhp seems plausible.

content: Many of its steel-bodied saloon contemporaries, the innovative method of manufacture employed in its construction is worthy of comment. Aside from being highly aerodynamic, the new car was also the first of the breed to benefit from a new fibreglass moulding process which Colin Chapman had been developing for some while. By this time, the owner of two boat-building concerns, Moonraker and JCL Marine, Colin had been seeking a way of using technology to reduce the time spent in the labour-intensive process of hand-laying glass-fibre. His solution, well-suited to both his marine and motoring requirements, was Vacuum-Assisted Resin Injection (VARI), in which pre-cut glass-fibre matting is laid into moulds and the air expelled as the resin mix is injected under pressure. When it came to the Elite, this meant building the new car in two halves, top and bottom, hence its distinctive and practical lateral rubbing strip which also serves to hide the join between the two halves. Using this efficient system for both his boats and cars, Colin saw an opportunity to secure great savings in time and labour. The Elite showed it could be made to work and before long the same new and innovative method was applied to other models.

The John Player Special Mark II, also known as the Lotus Type 77, was announced on the 18th of September 1975 and unveiled at a time when the team was widely perceived as having slipped behind several of its more important rivals in terms of both technical development and outright performance. As such, it was something of an interim measure, built to 'hold the fort' during the 1976 season, while work continued apace on the forthcoming but still top-secret Type 78. 

Based on a particularly slim aluminium monocoque designed by Geoff Aldridge, the Type 77 was the work of a team assembled under Peter Warr and comprising Aldridge, Mike Cooke, and Martin Ogilvie. The challenge was to clear away memories of the underwhelming Type 76 and to devise a workable and competitive, if temporary, replacement for the increasingly geriatric Type 72. 

At this time, the lengthy road circuits of the 1960s were being replaced by shorter, tighter circuits, a move which called for an entirely new approach to racing car design. Colin Chapman's solution was adjustable suspension, variable in both track and wheelbase as well as in several other key respects. The aim, naturally enough, was to reconcile the fact that on short, fast circuits, the car needed to be nimble and responsive.

By shorter, tighter circuits, a move which called for an entirely new approach to racing car design was necessary. Colin Chapman's solution was adjustable suspension, variable in both track and wheelbase, as well as in several other key respects. The aim was to reconcile the fact that on short, fast corners, short-wheelbase cars had the advantage, while on faster curves, it was the longer-wheelbase cars that took the lead.

Martin Ogilvie's solution to the problem of utilizing inboard brakes while securing total adjustability was a typically ingenious, if not Chapmanesque, arrangement whereby each brake's twin calipers were designed to double as structural suspension supports. In practice, Peterson left the track after coolant had leaked onto a rear tire, and in the race itself, the two cars collided.

Based on a substantially modified Europa Twin-Cam chassis, the razor-edged show car, internally designated Project M70, was destined to become the longest-running of all Lotus production cars when eventually christened the Esprit. Unquestionably one of the show's real stars, the new car was nevertheless painfully slow to develop, with that effort taking place over a two-year time span. The first pre-production prototype did not appear until late 1974, but the announcement of the production model itself was left until the following October. That made it almost three years since Giugiaro's exciting design had caught the public mood at Turin. The many well-publicized financial difficulties at Lotus conspired to slow the progress yet again, so that production of the Esprit did not start until well into 1976. However, unwelcome the record-breaking four-year gestation period was to prove, the mere fact that the car's design was still widely applauded when it finally went on sale says a lot for the enduring appeal of Giugiaro's original and futuristic 1972 design study.

At the Turin motor show in November 1972, Giorgetto Giugiaro's Ital Design studio had shown a stunning silver mid-engined concept car developed in close liaison with Lotus. In naming the car, Lotus continued with its alliterative tradition of leading with the letter ‘E’ and, to many ears, acquitted themselves successfully after the earlier choice of the somewhat awkward moniker given to the Éclat. The Esprit, while still a close-coupled two-seater, was intended from the start to be a larger, more usable machine than the pretty but occasionally claustrophobic Europa. More humble were the origins of the front suspension, which differed little from the set-up employed in several more mundane saloon cars of the day: double wishbones and coil-spring/damper assemblies with an anti-roll bar and solid disc brakes.

The independent rear suspension was, of course, more complex, comprising fixed-length driveshafts which doubled as the upper transverse links, lower transverse links, box-section semi-trailing arms, and coil-spring/damper units with inboard discs. Steering was by rack and pinion, unassisted in the early cars. The wheels were distinctive 14-inch diameter, 5-slot Wolf race alloys, with a black and silver Lotus center-cap, 6-inch wide at the front and 7-inch at the rear. content: After the first test of the radical new John Player Special Mark III, Mario Andretti famously described the handling of the Lotus Type 78 as "painted to the road." Certainly, to the invited audience at the launch party on December 21st, 1976, at London’s Royal Garden Hotel, the car looked like a winner, even if its appearance was so strikingly different from anything that had gone before. In 1977, the car's performance was impressive, boasting a top speed of 126 mph.

Clearly disturbed by the relatively poor performance of the Type 76, in the summer of 1975 Chapman had shut himself away to think of a solution and decided that what he and his team needed was a 'wing car'. In a detailed 27-page document, he set out his ideas and requirements before handing the project on to Tony Rudd, the hugely talented Rolls-Royce trained engineer who had served with such distinction at BRM. Inspiration for the car came from many sources, notable among them the inner wing section of the deHavilland Mosquito, and Rudd set out to devise a car which used its entire form to shape its aerodynamics instead of one which sought merely to compensate for an aerodynamically redundant shape by adding wings in the conventional manner. Maximum downforce with minimum drag became the team's new Holy Grail. The resulting monocoque was as slim as that fitted to the Type 77, but with wide panniers either side, a structural top panel above the driver's legs and, for the first time at Lotus, its construction made extensive use of Cellite, a sandwich of super-thin Dural panels enclosing a complex aluminum honeycomb. Strong, light, and extremely stiff, this was developed.

Strong, light, and extremely stiff, this was developed primarily for the aerospace industry. The big innovation this time concerned the radiators. DeHavilland-style leading-edge intakes fed cool air in, with hot air exiting through top ducts. These, and other modifications, like the endplate bristle-skirt which extended down to track level, functioned to generate two distinctly separate airflow patterns – one beneath the car and another around its upper and side surfaces. The result of all this development work, much of it carried out at the Imperial College wind-tunnel and led by chief-aerodynamicist Peter Wright, was an artificially-created drop in air pressure beneath the car which literally sucked the car down onto the track. Assisted by conventional wings and fins to provide additional stability and balance at speed, the Type 78 was shaping up to be a formidable machine. Once again, Team Lotus opted for Cosworth DFV power mated to a Hewland FG400 gearbox.

content: In July 1978, Lotus issued a press release detailing substantial modifications to the Esprit specification and dubbed the new car the Series 2. The blade style front spoiler was dropped for a more integrated under-bumper wrap-around style that let the factory quote a new aerodynamic Cd figure for the Esprit of 0.335. The top speed claim remained at 138 mph, but the most noticeable driving change was apparently enhanced cross-wind stability, provided by the integrated front spoiler. The new Lotus-designed, 4-spoke Speedline wheels were a little wider (7-inch front and 7.5-inch rear) than the Series 1, and partly in an effort to alleviate the lack of space under the front bonnet and partly to save costs, a smaller 'get you home' spare wheel was adopted. Other external changes included the use of black chip-resistant paint on the front spoiler, sill, and valance, and the addition of protruding engine air intakes positioned just behind the rear quarter windows. On Series 1 cars, the only air coming into the engine compartment was drawn from underneath the car, and it was hoped that bringing in cleaner, fresher air would help with engine cooling, as well as clean running in wet conditions.

content: With two more victories in 1978, Team Lotus set a new record, taking more checkered flags in one season than any team since Mercedes-Benz with their Silver Arrows in 1955. Tony Southgate's return to Shadow and Ralph Bellamy's departure to join the Fittipaldi brothers' Copersucar team meant Colin Chapman was more closely involved with the development of the Type 79 than with any of its immediate predecessors. Assisted by Ogilvie and Aldridge, he turned away from more extensive use of Cellite honeycomb sandwiches and instead devised a relatively conventional sheet aluminum monocoque as narrow as practicable, with a single large fuel cell in the space behind the driver and in front of the engine. The new Type 79, or John Player Special Mark IV as it was officially known, won six World Championship Grand Prix races in a single season, doing much to secure Colin Chapman's reputation as the most successful racing car designer in the history of Formula 1. However, this return to 'traditional' materials did not signify Colin's rejection of continual advance and innovation. With Southgate and Bellamy now working elsewhere, the team continued to push the boundaries of automotive design.

It was officially known that Colin Chapman's reputation as the most successful racing car designer in the history of Formula 1 was well-deserved. This return to 'traditional' materials did not in any way signify Colin's rejection of continual advance and innovation. With Southgate and Bellamy now working elsewhere on 'wing cars' of their own, he was anything but keen to abandon his dream and was still determined to find the extra 25 percent of aerodynamic effect which he calculated had been 'lost' as the Type 78 project had progressed from wind-tunnel test model to successful Grand Prix car. This time, Colin and his team opted for huge bolt-on fibreglass side-pods, so that from above the square-cut machine formed a perfect rectangle. Each pod was configured to act as a giant venturi, with the air entering at the front and accelerating to exit at the rear, where skirts sealed the U-shaped section to maintain the integrity of the underbody low-pressure area. The visual effect was stunning, at least with the bodywork all in place, and with some justification, the latest JPS-liveried car became known in Formula 1 circles as "Black Beauty." Among other mechanical changes, Colin was still determined.

Martini sponsorship meant the cars continued to be given chassis numbers with the team's sponsor ML prefix, as well as the traditional format such as 80-1, the car seen here. Once again, Colin's intention was to maximize the underwing area in order to secure the greatest possible advantage in terms of downforce, generated by a combination of large ground-effect sidepods and sliding skirts. By dispensing with drag-inducing wings and instead relying on modest trim tabs for aerodynamic fine-tuning, Colin estimated that when Mario Andretti took the car out for testing, he would gain the equivalent of 50 bhp.

Using the Cosworth DFV engine with a new gearbox (basically a Hewland FGA in a unique transversely split Lotus casing mounted between twin venturis), the car carried over many features from the Type 79, including driver-adjustable anti-roll bars fore and aft, near-identical suspension geometry, and a similar weight distribution. At a cold Brands Hatch circuit on the 16th of March 1979, ice and snow having forced the postponement of the following afternoon's Race of Champions, the Martini Racing-Team Lotus Type 80, Colin Chapman's 'wingless wonder', continued the company's established tradition of innovation and ground-breaking design. The 1979 Formula 1 Type 80 featured an aluminium monocoque chassis, with the weight being kept down by the use of titanium in place of the Type 79's mild steel, and extensive use inside and out of aluminium honeycomb sheet. It had originally been hoped to employ titanium for fabricating the upper rocking arms as well, but in the event, the complex welds required proved unsuited to the application. Subject to later revision, the brakes were initially placed inboard at the rear and outboard at the front.

Keen to maximise negative lift while minimising drag, Colin had opted for a long nose section with the side skirts extending the entire length of the curved body sides, with only minimal breaks to allow for the suspension. It became clear in early testing, however, that these skirts would be the source of many problems. Pitching of the nose – known as 'porpoising' – was an enduring problem.

content: With the side skirts extending the entire length of the curved body sides, with only minimal breaks to allow for the suspension, it became clear in early testing that these skirts would be the source of many problems. Pitching of the nose – known as ‘porpoising’, an enduring problem with rival Niki Lauda’s Brabham BT48 as well – damaged the front sections of each skirt. In addition, the main skirts frequently stuck in their housings if one end lifted significantly relative to the other. In this way, downforce would be lost, being restored suddenly and at the most unpredictable moments – in other words, just when the driver was least expecting it. As always, the team was ready with a pragmatic solution, quickly modifying the skirts and applying wings to the nose section in time for Andretti’s teammate Carlos Reutemann to test the car at Donington. By the time the car was readied for the re-scheduled Race of Champions in mid-April, it had gained a rear wing also, although oil-spill problems forced Andretti back into his Type 79 for the race itself. With Reutemann refusing to drive the new car, its race debut finally came at the end.

content:
The Sunbeam Lotus Type 81 was an homologation special built for rallying, but not coincidentally, also an exciting and involving road car. It appeared very much in the Vauxhall Chevette HS2300/Ford Escort RS1600 mould. The parent company Talbot claimed it to be "the perfect embodiment of the new spirit of motoring" in their advertising blurb at the time. With its 'impeccable pedigree,' it was planned as a unique specialist vehicle combining high performance, luxury, and excellent engineering. More significantly, perhaps, it was also to prove capable of beating even the mighty Audi Quattro, defeating both German technology and Rothmans' massive financial backing to take the Rally World Championship in 1981.

The idea of a rally car for the road appealed enormously to the relevant Chrysler (later Talbot) dealer network. And for Lotus, the car’s arrival was timely too, as the earlier collapse of Jensen had left the company with a need to find another major customer for its 907-based range of engines. With two names rich in motorsport heritage – Sunbeam’s many successes may have come earlier than those of Lotus but they were scarcely less distinguished – expectations were high.

Despite these quite significant mechanical changes, the list price for a new S2.2 Esprit was, at £14,951, virtually unchanged from the price of the last of the S2 models, which were being sold through Lotus dealers at £14,884. Less than a year later, the price had risen to £15,720, making the car an expensive proposition in comparison to its rivals.

In April 1981, after just 93 examples of the Esprit S2.2 had been built, production of the original body shape Esprit ended to be replaced by the long awaited and much needed new shape Turbo Esprit (Type 82) and the 'Turbo-bodied' but normally aspirated Esprit Series 3 (Type 85).

Announced in April of 1980 at the same time as the S2.2 versions of both the Elite and Éclat, the revised Esprit S2.2, still built under the Type 79 designation, featured the new larger capacity version of the Type 907 power-unit, dubbed Type 912.

Intended to boost the engine’s power output to an impressive 210bhp at 6,250rpm (and requiring a one-inch wider clutch to be fitted along with larger, non-ventilated brakes), the addition heralded the arrival of the Esprit as a genuine 150mph+ Lotus supercar. With the transition from Essex limited edition to Lotus Turbo Esprit in April of 1981, the company slashed the price from £21,000 to just £16,917, relocated the radio-cassette unit to a more sensible slot and put the pricey air-conditioning back on to the ever-growing 'optional extras' list. At a time of global economic upheaval, these contracts also provided badly needed cash for substantial model improvements which were long overdue. The most important modification to the six-year-old Elite was its enlarged engine, announced in April 1980, up from 2-litres to 2.2. The new engine was identified as the Type 912. To avoid confusion, it should be noted that while similar in many respects to the Type 911 engine developed for the Sunbeam Lotus rally car project, this was for Lotus an entirely new engine. In fact, the 912 engine offered no more power than its predecessor—peak output was still 160bhp, but it was available at 6,500rpm instead of the older engine’s 6,200—but it gained much needed torque and this was available across a wider spread of the vehicle’s range. Fuel efficiency for the car, confusingly known both as the Elite S2 and as the S2.2 for obvious reasons, was also much improved.

Mechanically, other changes included chassis revisions whereby the frame remained essentially the same but was now hot-dipped in zinc to provide corrosion protection. The car gained a new five-speed Getrag gearbox in place of the company’s own which had proved less reliable.

A Borg-Warner three-speed automatic remained on the list of optional extras, but priced at £260 it proved no more popular than it had on the Series 1 Elite; Lotus drivers clearly still preferred changing gear themselves. Externally, the most obvious modification was to the front spoiler, which now blended in more smoothly with the bodywork as well as the new sills beneath the doors. And at the other end of the car, the tailgate gained a new external locking catch and the hatchback wiper was remounted into the glass, instead of on the bodywork below the hatch. Inside, the cabin was much as before with the same basic controls and instrument layout as on the original 1974 car but with different trim detailing, new seats, and new seatbelts. Even small changes like this meant that prices rose accordingly.

Towards the end of 1981, as the factory prepared to celebrate the production of its 20,000th quad-valve engine, the predicted recession finally hit Britain, and with the Elite S2 now priced at £17,206, sales of the car went into decline: from around 250 in 1979 to perilously close to 100 a year later, and by 1981 down to just one a month. The sport felt instead to be an entirely new rule. "We have no doubt," reported Autosport. By late November 1979, with testing continuing at Paul Ricard, it was clear that Colin Chapman and his team were falling behind the many technical developments underway within rival teams. Performance was soaring and lap times dropping week by week; what Team Lotus had introduced with ground effects and sliding skirts, Williams and Brabham had taken further. In addition, the turbocharged cars of another team, Renault, were soon threatening to render uncompetitive the normally-aspirated Cosworth DFVs of teams like Lotus.

Against this background, Colin abandoned attempts to develop the Type 80 to a point where it would be truly competitive. After FISA moved to ban sliding skirts, Lotus instead began a search for a magic ingredient to resolve the mutual incompatibility of suspension requirements between those parts of the car which affect its aerodynamics and those parts which insulate the driver from the road shocks. Thus was born the concept of two separate chassis with two separate suspension systems. As Formula 1 moved towards almost go-kart-like parameters with wheel travel reduced to as little as one inch, Colin and his team explored new possibilities.

content: The aerodynamics and the parts that insulate the driver from road shocks are crucial. This led to the concept of two separate chassis with two separate suspension systems. As Formula 1 evolved towards go-kart-like parameters, with wheel travel reduced to as little as one inch, Colin and the team engineers at Ketteringham Hall focused their efforts on finding a viable solution to the problem of aerodynamic and suspension loading. Soon, they completed a so-called 'technology demonstrator,' the result of three years of meticulous and innovative research and development, which began with the Type 80. Significantly, the car was designed to meet the FISA regulations of the period, which allowed the use of skirts. In a December issue of a magazine, it was stated, "The Lotus 86 has been built to comply with the rules as written, and there is little doubt that an attempt will be made to get those rules re-written to render it (the new car) illegal." Colin Chapman likely felt the same way but was still convinced that he would eventually be able to justify a practical racing version of the car.

In the preceding years, Lotus prices had risen sharply, and new-car sales dropped accordingly from around 1,200 units a year to just 383, a dangerous scenario for any relatively small-scale producer, even one as well respected as Lotus. Growing co-operation with Toyota had given Lotus access to the Japanese company’s vast parts bin, but the later purchase of Group Lotus by General Motors meant that the Excel would be the only Lotus badged fruit of this union. There was plenty of engineering consultancy work between the two companies, but at the time this was on a strictly confidential basis and little was known outside Hethel. Qualifying seventh and settling into fifth, De Angelis moved up to fourth after one of the Renaults retired, then third as Piquet pitted to refuel. When the other Brabham's engine blew, De Angelis suddenly found himself in second place, tightly sandwiched between Alain Prost's leading Renault and a hard-charging Rosberg in the Williams. With just half a dozen laps to go (and Mansell long out of the running), Prost's injection system faltered then failed, and with Rosberg battling to overtake him, De Angelis took the flag by the scant margin of just 0.05 seconds. His first Grand Prix win, it was the first for Team Lotus since the 1978 Dutch GP at Zandvoort, and must have been a golden moment for Colin Chapman. Sadly, it would prove to be the last time we would see the famous Colin Chapman victory celebration.

content: To do this, and in the hope that the resulting machine would remain competitive in the hands of Nigel Mansell, he knew he needed something special, a magic ingredient. So it was that he decided to incorporate into the new Type 92 a computer-controlled 'active' suspension system that Team Lotus had had under development for so long. This system, while comparatively heavy with around 20 kilograms of hardware and requiring an additional 1.5 gallons of hydraulic fluid, was certainly clever. Designed and developed in partnership with Britain's Cranfield College of Aeronautics, it featured hydraulic rams on all four corners which were powered by a small centrally-located engine-driven pump. These rams effectively replaced the springs, anti-roll bars, and dampers and were controlled from a central processing unit (CPU) which received telemetric data from a battery of accelerometers as well as load sensors and transducers mounted on each ram. By analyzing the electronic input from these sensors, the CPU was able to build a 'picture' of the vehicle's movements and attitudes. Receiving signals back from the CPU, the suspension rams were then able to react almost instantaneously by extending or shortening the suspension travel to optimize the chassis attitude and control.

In February 1983, Team Lotus announced the installation at the team's Ketteringham Hall base of a massive oven capable of swallowing an entire racing car chassis, and wheeled out the fruits of its first new 'recipe', the John Player Special Type 93T. Still reeling from the sudden, unexpected death of Colin Chapman, the team felt it had to press on, and had reasonable cause for optimism with its all carbon-fibre/Kevlar chassis and what was considered the best engine in Formula 1 to power it. The new car promised to be "even stronger, lighter yet stiffer." It was also built larger to afford the driver greater protection, using space-age materials including a carbon-fibre/Kevlar mix which was pre-soaked in resin (a world-first) and built into layer form with a Nomex paper honeycomb forming the meat in the sandwich. The entire ensemble was then, in the words of the factory press handout, "literally baked at 125C." The team also announced a switch to radial-ply Pirellis, to Elf lubricants, and to Champion spark plugs, but of course, the most important new ingredient was that designated by the suffix 'T' – Renault's V6, 90-degree 1,492cc EF1 engine, with twin KKK turbochargers.

With the factory working double shifts seven days a week, the new cars were readied for the all-important British Grand Prix. Substantially different from the car it replaced, the Type 94T had new suspension (abandoning the pull-rod design), new bodywork, new gearbox, even new pedals. That said, it retained the impressively strong carbon-fibre/Kevlar chassis, and the means of production remained much as before. It also retained much that had served to distinguish the earlier Type 91, Ducarouge having realized that to meet the extremely short deadline, he needed to adapt something from somewhere. The smaller and more compact Type 91 monocoque was chosen over its immediate descendants. The Type 91’s design allowed for easy removal of the front and rear bulkheads, the latter of which proved easy to adapt to take the altered mountings for the Renault V6. The fuel cell was also modified to include a different breather and filler neck designed to suit the new system of mid-race refuelling stops. Revised positioning of the intercoolers and radiators made for different weight distribution while a completely new car was born.

content: Unveiled in London on 3rd February 1987, the new Lotus Type 99T was the first Lotus Grand Prix car to be Honda-powered and, according to Gerard Ducarouge, was "a classic car based on the previous three." Using the turbocharged Honda V6s, the 80-degree RA166-E then later the RA167-G – both substantially more powerful than the ageing Renault engines – it saw a return to the method of construction used prior to 1986, the Lotus monocoque once more being built up using a folded single carbon-fibre/Kevlar composite sheet. The car was, according to Ducarouge, "a much refined development of our previous designs, 95T, 97T, and 98T. The difference in the new car is not really on the surface but under the skin, as we had to produce a new carbon-fibre/Kevlar chassis designed to accommodate the Honda engine. We followed our well-tried and tested formula in the design, in order to try to get the best from the Japanese engine." The very wide power range of this high-revving engine required the development by Lotus and Hewland of a new six-speed gearbox. With the car being primarily a new bodyshell on top of an existing and well-proven chassis/engine combination, its development from start to finish had taken just 15 months, an incredibly short time to design what to the outside world seemed to be a new car.

Official production figures from Lotus Cars confirm that over 1600 Esprit Turbo SEs were made between 1989 and 1993, making it second only to the 1980-87 models in turbocharged popularity. Its annual sales rates were higher than those of the originals, partially because the same power-trains and substantially the same car could be sold in all markets. If Lotus had a first 'world car', the Esprit SE was that machine.

Key components of the revised car were assembled around the 910S-coded version of the familiar 4-cylinder, 16-valve unit with its single Garrett TB03 turbocharger, complete with water cooling and integral wastegate adopted in previous editions. The big changes were the installation of Delco Electronics’ GMP4 engine management that superseded the previous American emission specification and the more stringent European emission specification for markets like Switzerland. The latter gave 228 horsepower but was a low volume item sold only from September 1988 compared to the US Bosch fuel injection variants spanning 1985-1988.

The big bonus with GMP4 electronics and the new distributor-less twin coil ignition system was that the turbocharged twin-cam motor could release more reliable power on low-grade, 95 RON minimum, unleaded fuels.

content: The patented 'active wishbone' design from Lotus engineers Jerry Booen and John Miles, the former Grand Prix driver who played a significant role in developing the car's ride and handling, looked set to mark this car out from its rivals. Conventional wishbones, mounted as they are directly onto the chassis, need to employ soft bushes to eliminate noise, vibration, and harshness. Handling suffers as a result, hence Miles and Booen's decision to mount their wishbones as stiffly as possible and to do it using metal and rubber bushing rather than just rubber. This done, Lotus believed the car would be able to maintain its optimum suspension geometry under the hardest of cornering, braking, and – doubtless most significantly for the ever-growing list of customers placing orders at the dealers – acceleration. It worked too; Car magazine called the resulting machine a real winner. By the time the cars were in production, pent-up demand ensured a healthy start with 1,200 Elans in their owners' garages by the end of 1990. A handful of non-turbo versions of the car were in fact ordered and sold, but almost all Type 100 Elans were produced as the turbocharged SE model. Eventually, when a recession hit, the car's production was affected.

Sponsorship for the 1989 effort once again came from Camel and Epson.

Magnificent, decidedly brutal, and quite different from anything ever to wear the Lotus badge, when the prototype Lotus Carlton – or Lotus Omega if ordered with left-hand-drive – was first seen at the 1989 Geneva Show, its proposed specification stunned the motoring press and public alike. The car was clearly an attempt to recreate the magic and marketing impact of the famous Lotus-Cortina. Naturally enough, this time the tie-up was with General Motors, the new car being based on the seemingly innocuous, and not especially well-liked, Vauxhall Carlton shell. But there was nothing innocuous about the finished result. Wild flared arches, skirts, tremendously wide wheels, a deep chin spoiler and numerous other aerodynamic add-ons gave the car fantastic visual appeal even without the plethora of little Lotus badges on both body and engine which served to further underline this super-sports saloon’s massive potential.

This time, unlike the Lotus Cortina and Lotus Sunbeam, there were no competition objectives for the new car. This was to be a road-car, pure and simple, a genuine four-door, five-seater, but with the performance and handling to rival most supercars and any of the more obviously sporting coupés. GM’s Bob Eaton was clear about what his car was meant to achieve.

This was to be a road-car, pure and simple, a genuine four-door, five-seater, but with the performance and handling to rival most supercars and any of the more obviously sporting coupes. GM’s Bob Eaton was clear about what his organization wanted from the Type 104: something to enable Opel and Vauxhall to shed their humdrum image and to bring a bit of bravado to their cars. To do for them, in other words, precisely what the Cosworth range had done for rival Ford's Escorts and Sierras. For the development team at Lotus, the objective was even simpler: to build the world's fastest saloon. To do this, the company took as its starting point the range-topping 24-valve three-litre Omega, the finished cars being shipped from Opel at Russelheim in Germany for a complete strip-down and rebuild on a new line at Hethel.

Type 104

By increasing both the bore and stroke of the existing straight-six engine, the engine capacity was increased to 3.6 liters; a new cylinder head and twin Garrett AiResearch T25 blowers and intercoolers took the unit's output from 204 bhp and 199 lb of torque to a quite staggering 377 bhp at 5,200 rpm and 419 lb of torque at 4,200 rpm. Transmission was via a six-speed ZF gearbox (from the Lotus-developed Corvette ZR1), now equipped with a limited-slip differential.

This unprecedented power hike necessitated substantial modifications to the suspension as well, which was accordingly uprated with a self-leveling arrangement to the rear. Ventilated disc brakes were fitted all around. The interior was uprated too, with new seats using Connolly hides and revised instrumentation.

Whilst the car's boot-mounted rear wing was actually quite modest for its time, there was no doubting the Batmobile-like visual impact of the finished car. The tire and wheel combination said it all: 17x8.5-inch front rims with 235/45ZR17 tires and still larger ones at the back, 9.5-inch rims with 265/40ZR17 rubber. This was a very serious machine indeed, and the company was proud of its claim that the Carlton's revised aerodynamics gave it an enhanced 0.31 Cd.

This was a very serious machine indeed, and the company was proud of its claim that the Carlton's revised aerodynamics gave it an enhanced 0.31 Cd while ensuring that it remained stable throughout its considerable speed range. How considerable? General Motors admitted to recording 176 mph on a closed circuit in Italy with a 0-62 mph time of 5.4 seconds. On the road, the car achieved "over 174 mph" with one UK-based motoring magazine recording, for the first time in its long history, in-gear acceleration figures for 140-160 mph. Though launched at Geneva in 1989, it was a year before the company actually started shipping cars. By that time, many journalists had switched from criticizing the car as "merely a Vauxhall" to praising it as the magnificent, well-sorted beast it was. Despite a reasonable entry price of £48,000, by the time production ceased in 1992, the original sales target of some 1,100 had not been reached. Vauxhall records showed 440 completed Carltons, and Opel just over 500 Omegas, for a grand total of 950, including prototypes.

The inspiration for the program had come from the United States, but it sat well with an idea for a Porsche 911-beating Esprit which had long been occupying test driver and development engineer at Lotus Cars in the UK, Roger Becker's fertile mind. content:
A lot of expertise and materials from existing programmes. Besides the ditching of many unnecessary ancillaries, the use of polycarbonate windows and, where possible, lightweight panels, brought the car down to a dry weight of 2,400lb. The biggest visible changes were the relocation of the rear wing and an extended front spoiler. The chassis was left ungalvanised, saving a further 17.6lb, and the car was equipped with an FIA-approved roll cage, fitted to the suspension towers at each corner to improve chassis stiffness. Revised suspension geometries altered the caster and dive characteristics, and the ride-height was reduced by some 10mm.

While based on the two left-hand-drive racing cars, the 20 cars, which needed to be built to ensure Homologation for racing, naturally gained an improved specification. This included air conditioning on all but one of the 20, an interior re-trimmed with charcoal doeskin fabric, new Lotus sports seats, three-point seatbelts, and an RAC-approved club roll cage. Features stripped out to save weight in the race cars – including glass windows, a heater, and the chassis galvanisation – were restored for the road cars.

Development was once again left to John Miles and Roger Becker, and the end result was a car with the following stats:

Weight was reduced in the race cars by stripping out elements such as glass windows, a heater, and the chassis galvanization, which were restored for the road cars. Development was entrusted to John Miles and Roger Becker, resulting in a car that was two seconds per lap faster than the standard production model. The 264bhp 16-valve turbocharged four-cylinder engine enabled a zero to 60mph time of just 4.7 seconds and a top speed exceeding 160mph.

The Esprit SE (SCCA), Type 105, saw the incorporation of uprated brakes from the Lotus Carlton, with 13-inch discs at the front and 11-inch at the rear, along with 4-piston alloy AP calipers. The wheels were also new: Revolution three-piece racing alloys (15-inch front and 16-inch rear) with Goodyear Eagle ZR tires (225/45s front and 255/50s rear). Competition-grade Monroe shock absorbers were installed, and later on, an electronic Lotus-GM ABS braking system was added.

The engine was blueprinted, using Lotus Carlton injectors, and in a test, one of the two race cars had the air-conditioning radiator ingeniously repurposed by being integrated into the chargecooler system. With a reprogrammed engine management system, the motor was capable of producing between 285 and 300bhp.

content: In 1993, the Lotus Sport run Type 106 Esprit racecar team faced one of the problems that has dogged Lotus over the years, namely being too successful. After the first two races of the season, both won by Lotus, one each for Doc Bundy and David Murray, IMSA (the ruling body) decided to change the championship rules to clearly favor the Porsches. By offering a bonus five championship points for pole position and two points for second on the grid, it would be almost impossible for a Lotus to win the series again. The Porsche cars held an advantage of almost 100 bhp over the Esprits, and they would always be able to take pole position, with the additional points available in practice. In the race, though, the better handling and more nimble Esprits were usually able to overcome this power advantage to win over the Porsches, but nonetheless, the points advantage gained in practice was always going to be too great for the Lotus team cars to overcome. In a further attempt to slow the Esprit and to add insult to injury, IMSA next changed the rules on turbocharger outputs. This further restricted the Type 106’s performance.

content: Murphy and his team had originally intended to use a Judd V10 engine for this new car until negotiations with Britain’s Vickers PLC opened up the possibility of Team Lotus co-operating with its subsidiary Cosworth. Most significantly, this change of direction marked a renewal of the alliance between the Lotus Formula 1 team and the Ford brand-name, evoking memories of the partnership’s historic debut victory at Zandvoort in 1967. That victory by Jim Clark was the first of 155 for the famous DFV (Double-Four-Valve) engine and its derivatives, and with its new engine, the HB Series V – at the time the fastest revving V8 in history – Ford hoped to repeat the magic. With at least 730bhp available at a crank speed in the region of 13,500rpm, Lotus and its new main sponsor Castrol (who signed up in time for the British Grand Prix) must have hoped so too. The venture was not, journalists were told, merely “an exercise in nostalgia,” but a genuine bid for victory. The engine itself, a 75-degree vee of 3,494cc used an aluminium crankcase and cylinder heads, manufactured in Cosworth’s Worcester foundry. Other componentry was of carbon composite, titanium, and magnesium.

The engine itself, a 75-degree V8 of 3,494cc, used an aluminium crankcase and cylinder heads, manufactured in Cosworth’s Worcester foundry. Other componentry was of carbon composite, titanium, and magnesium; it was therefore a sophisticated ensemble, certainly more expensive than the previous year’s Judd V10 package, but hopefully worth it. And once the deal was struck, Murphy seemed extremely happy with the new engine, admitting it allowed him to "get the weight exactly where we wanted it." Power was transmitted to the wheels via a six-speed transverse mounted gearbox, in another Team Lotus-designed casing, this time though housing X-trac sourced internals.

In true Chapman style, simplicity and lightness were Murphy’s twin objectives throughout the project, and the finished car came very close to the minimum weight limit then in force. His pursuit of state-of-the-art aerodynamics – developed in the team’s own wind-tunnel – concentrated on the car’s front end, particularly around the nose wings. For Team Lotus, the best race of the year had come as part of a mid-season run of competitiveness that culminated at Magny-Cours for the French GP. After qualifying in strong tenth and eleventh places, Hakkinen and Herbert brought the cars across the line in an excellent fourth and sixth places.

Called the Lotus Sport Bicycle, the Type 108 was developed and tested in secret during early 1992 and saw an immediate and marked improvement in the times recorded by its riders. The key to the bike's incredible performance was its aerofoil-section composite monocoque, moulded using a range of advanced materials, but principally carbon-fibre. Both at competition and general-usage level, Lotus had by 1992 considerable experience with these materials and were able to design and develop a machine which minimized the aerodynamic drag of both bike and rider. By Spa they had it sorted, and although Herbert qualified only tenth, he made it home in fifth place.

Although Lotus was working on the development of a totally new car, there was still life in the innovative Elan. In 1994, fully 18 months after it had been discontinued, a limited edition production run of 800 examples of the Type 100 was released. Using the 800 remaining Isuzu engine/gearbox units and the production line at Hethel that was still pretty much intact, it was relatively easy for the new regime to bring the Elan back to life. Unveiled at the 1994 Geneva Motorshow, the 'new' model, now called Elan S2, was distinguished by new style larger diameter 16-inch, 5-spoke wheels and a numbered plate on the dashboard of each car.

content:
The Elan was intact, making it relatively easy for the new regime to bring it back to life. Unveiled at the 1994 Geneva Motor Show, the 'new' model, now called Elan S2, was distinguished by its new style, larger diameter 16-inch, 5-spoke wheels, and a numbered plate on the dashboard of each car. The Series 2 retained the Type 100 designation. The list price for the car, now only available in turbocharged form, was up to £24,500, available for the European market only. With the enforced addition of a catalytic converter, engine power was reduced by 10bhp to 155, the same figure as the catalyst-equipped federal specification car. The inevitable increase in overall weight resulted in an increased 0–60mph acceleration time.

Engineers at Lotus also took the opportunity to make revisions to the suspension, damper, and steering set-up, which some had felt was over-assisted. Stiffer bushings were used in the rafts to give a firmer ride, and the power steering was re-valved to give improved feel. The rear suspension top link was also redesigned to reduce cost, and the anti-lock brakes were re-calibrated.

The UK edition of Car Magazine, on driving the S2, said, "The Elan has never been about pure muscle; it's about agility and handling."

content: While Team Lotus was clearly pleased with its new exclusive Japanese engine deal with Mugen-Honda, the situation at the F1 HQ at Ketteringham Hall was still far from happy. In September, a firm of accountants had been appointed as the team's joint administrators. Johnny Herbert was still evidently keen to be leaving Lotus altogether, and even the most ardent enthusiast for the marque could not help noticing that Honda's V10 was somewhat old compared to many of its most important rivals on the grid. It certainly had the required strength and power, particularly at the top end, but even the optimists recognized that it was still only really a derivative of the engine campaigned by Alain Prost as long ago as 1989. There was, it is true, a new engine due from Honda, but by the time the ink had dried on the Mugen deal it was clear it would not be ready before the start of the season. That left Lotus to begin its fight back with its ageing 107 chassis, now in 'D' form, having been modified to take the Honda unit. The team's performance in the early rounds was thus somewhat lackluster.

The team was not ready before the start of the season. That left Lotus to begin its fight back with its ageing 107 chassis, now in 'D' form, having been modified to take the Honda unit. The team's performance in the early rounds was somewhat lackluster, with Herbert being placed no higher than seventh in any of the races run before the new cars arrived. The best that can be said for the car was that it was at least consistent and reliable. Finally, in time for the Barcelona round, the new Type 109 was ready to be wheeled out. In fact, it was very much a reworked 107 and actually did little for results until Monza, when, possibly a few weeks ahead of schedule, Herbert's car received the first of the new 72-degree ZA6C engines, enabling him to qualify fourth on the grid—a rare glimmer of light in an otherwise depressing and dark season for Team Lotus.

With less weight and a lower center of gravity, the car had seemed much improved and well suited to the track at Monza. But even this did little, if anything, to persuade Herbert to stick with the team.

That said, testing the revised car at Silverstone, Herbert was able to find an additional three seconds per lap with the new engine, in theory enough to bring him to within one second of Schumacher. Overlapping the first year of V8 production, the Esprit S4S spanned the three years from 1994 to 1997 with a total of 367 examples made. Essentially, the new S4S brought the higher power 2.2-litre turbo motor of the Sport 300 to a broader market, and at around £10,000 less. This meant a saving of just over £12,000 compared to the Sport 300 but an increase of £4,000 against the standard S4, which remained in production alongside the S4S until 1996. The S4S featured some civilized touches that were not appropriate to the more focused road racer Sport 300. These included a more accessible torque curve and a softer ride on split-rim, 3-piece, OZ ‘Futura’ wheels and Michelin tyre combination, coupled to Brembo brake components rather than the AP system.

The petrol-injected engine remained at a Sport 300 level of 300bhp (peak), now at an elevated 7000rpm, but maximum torque was much more friendly at 290lbft by 3600rpm, with a reported 80 per cent of maximum torque available between 2500 and 6000rpm. As on the Sport 300, the hybrid Garrett T3/T4 turbocharger was employed – with water cooling – and the inlet valves were enlarged.

content: During 1993 and 1994, the distinctive green and yellow race versions of the Sport 300 Esprit had proved successful in the hands of the Chamberlain Engineering team. The cars had been developed along the same route as the Types 105 and 106 for the USA series, and their highly competitive performances prompted Group Lotus to become more seriously involved. By 1995, classified as the official works team, the Lotus Esprit GT team entered the Karcher Global Endurance GT Series four-hour race at Donington with a new-look racing car, but still designated Type 82, which had been developed during the closed season. It was, as such, the first Lotus works-entry in a sports car category since 1969, marking the next step in the company’s declared strategy to return to its former pre-eminent position in the international motorsport arena. Qualifying to run in the immensely competitive GT2 category, the car was driven by a partnership of ex-Formula 1 driver Alessandro Zanardi (formerly with Team Lotus where he had driven the Type 107B and 109). In 1995, the Esprit GT2 Racecar, Type 82, set the fastest GT2 lap of the race, outperforming their class rivals.

1996 marked the beginning of a new era for Lotus with the excitement of a V8 racecar. Created alongside the 1996 road-going V8s, the racer had already been tested at Paul Ricard for some time, just four days before the showroom model was revealed. Along with these, a trio of very special V8 Esprits for Global GT1 racing were designated Type 114. The project team was given just 27 months to create, design, and build a unique power unit for a world-beating new supercar. A clean-sheet approach was adopted under the wing of former Ford engineer John Owen and Hugh Kemp, then director of powertrains at Lotus Engineering. In March 1996, an all-new Esprit GT1 racer was unveiled at the Paul Ricard circuit in France, the still-secret Lotus V8 lurking under its engine cover. Four days later, the secret was out, when the long-awaited 175mph Esprit V8 road car finally made its debut at the Geneva Motor Show.

Coded 918 in all its production formats and rated at the same maximum power and torque figures throughout its 1996-2003 production life, the Lotus eight was suitably high tech as the first new company production engine since the 907 of 1972. It sported 32-valves, four overhead camshafts, and twin turbochargers. Extreme power was not on the menu; 350bhp was the most frequently quoted, but 550bhp was possible from the single turbo race unit developed for the car.

content: Described with some justification by its makers as "the world's most advanced sports car," the Lotus Elise made its public debut at the Frankfurt Motor Show on the 12th of September, 1995. The Elise was quickly heralded as a new breed of supercar – small, high-tech, and simple, offering brilliant performance and handling for the enthusiastic driver, the hallmarks of many classic Lotus designs. Named after the granddaughter of the flamboyant Italian head of Bugatti Industries and Group Lotus chairman Romano Artioli, the all-new car featured a futuristic, yet practical and proven epoxy-bonded aluminum spaceframe chassis, clothed in a compact and highly distinctive body designed by a team headed up by Julian Thomson. The new Type 111 was intended from the start to be a particularly strong, ultra-light, very fast design and fun to drive – a new 'Seven for the 1990s'. The press and public certainly thought so, and it quickly racked up numerous awards for design and innovation, including Car of the Year (What Car?), Top Sports Car (BBC Top Gear Magazine), and Best Designed New Car (from a poll of Car Magazine readers). The new Lotus also reached the finals of the prestigious Prince of Wales Award.

It quickly racked up numerous awards for design and innovation, including Car of the Year (What Car?), Top Sports Car (BBC Top Gear Magazine), and Best Designed New Car (from a poll of Car Magazine readers). The new Lotus also reached the finals of the prestigious Prince of Wales Award for Innovation, picking up many other awards across Europe along the way. The novel construction, its all-up dry weight of only 690 kg (1520 lb), and hence the car's extremely high power-to-weight ratio, showed the company moving in a new direction. By seeking to minimize weight rather than simply maximizing power, Lotus aimed to improve on existing sports cars' braking, handling, and steering responses, while simultaneously reducing overall fuel consumption and carbon-dioxide emissions to more acceptable levels. In 1996, working with Hydro Aluminium Automotive Structures (which had also assisted Renault with the development of its rival, the heavier Sport Spider), the Elise demonstrated an entirely new approach to vehicle architecture and brought to roadcar design a truly affordable 'spaceframe' style structure. This was made of epoxy-bonded sections of anodized aluminum extrusions, the whole being clothed in composite body panels (constructed using the traditional hand-lay system) styled by Hethel's in-house design team.

The car’s unique steel subframe carried a transverse-mounted Rover K-Series engine: a 1.8-liter four-valve straight four developing 118 bhp and giving the car an effective 125 mph potential top speed with a 0-60 mph time of around 5.5 seconds. A particularly fine-tuned independent suspension system, comprising upper and lower wishbones, co-axial coil-springs, and inverted monotube dampers, ensured that the new car could provide the handling to match. And, just as importantly, the Elise was to be affordable. Lotus was planning an initial production run of 700 new cars per year. The Elise turned around the public’s perception of Lotus. content: Developed for the dedicated track fan and for fully-fledged motorsport applications, the Elise Sport 190 was a pure racer. At its heart was an extensively modified version of the standard 1.8-litre engine – each meticulously hand-built by race technicians at Hethel – kicking out a breathtaking 190bhp. This mighty powerplant was known, appropriately, as the VHPD, or Very High Performance Derivative, and could hurl the featherweight Sport 190 from standstill to 60mph in 4.3 seconds (0-100km/h in 4.4 seconds) and to 100mph in a supercar-bashing 10.72 seconds. As you would expect with this extraordinary level of performance, the Sport 190 was equipped with competition-modified suspension, brakes, wheels, and tyres, and an ultra-close-ratio gearbox, all fitted and set up by the same technicians who developed the car. Because each of the 48 Sport 190s was specially built to order by the Lotus aftermarket department (the prototype car pictured here was distinctively painted Chrome Green), each car could be tailored to specific customer requests; the list of options was extensive. The VHPD engine was the familiar transversely mid-mounted four-cylinder in-line, DOHC, four valves per cylinder unit. Changes over the standard engine comprised a modified cylinder head, valves, pistons, crankshaft, flywheel, and solid valve lifters.

With customers constantly asking for more power, Lotus had managed to keep them happy by offering several engine modification packs, such as (135, 160), but something more universal was clearly needed. Introduced in January of 1999, the Elise 111S was the first model in the Elise range to be equipped with the MG/Rover Variable Valve Control (VVC) engine, a power source that Lotus had been hoping to use since the first Elise had been launched back in 1996. Always part of the Elise master plan, but subject to Rover’s constraints of production and politics surrounding the MGF’s premium engine, the VVC-powered evolution of the Elise was formally announced at the Geneva Show in the spring of 1999, with production having already begun in January that year. The launch price was £26,590, some £3,915 more than the starter price of £22,675 for the Elise.

The 111S running gear showcased the Lotus-AP racing opposed piston calipers now working cross-drilled 282mm cast iron disc brakes, whilst the wheel and tyre specification was also enhanced. At the back, new 7.5x16-inch 6-spoke alloys wore 225/45 rears rather than 205/50s on 7-inch rims. Front wheels, also of the 6-spoke design, remained at 5.5x15-inch.

As Proton acquired the remaining shares in Lotus, the first year of the new millennium saw them building more cars than ever before in its 53-year history.

Although the 340R was a terrific track car, benefiting particularly from a new generation of A038 Yokohama tires on unique 12-spoke 6x15 and 8x16-inch wheels, it was the brainchild of Russell Carr at Lotus Design, rather than the engineering division. content: The Sport 160 and its earlier cousin, the Sport 190, were quite different engineering extensions of the Sport philosophy beyond the mild, but effective, Sport 135 offered earlier. The 160 was always destined for the showroom as well as the track, powered by a seriously redeveloped power unit that dated back to Rover’s proposed one-make series for their 200 model in 1995, which was dropped after the BMW takeover of Rover. The Elise Sport 160 had a much simpler production life than the 190, serving as a hugely popular run-out horsepower special. Just 319 were made in two batches, and the specification was as flexible as that of any Elise, with some important options. The first 50 Sport 160 cars underwent Single Vehicle type Approval (SVA) testing and were built at the factory with catalytic converters and 'Sport' exhaust mufflers to produce 160 PS. The Elise Sport 160 was introduced in February of 2000 as a high-performance derivative of the Elise aimed at customers who wanted an increased level of dynamic specification for use on both the road and track.

The new version of the Elise was rolled out and christened simply 'Sport Elise'. Still officially a Type 111, it featured a range of Sport Original Performance Products and was intended for circuit use only. Powered by a 200bhp version of the Rover K-Series, it also received changes to the cylinder head, valves, pistons, crankshaft, and flywheel and was fitted with solid valve lifters to give a maximum engine speed of 8,000rpm. With 283bhp per tonne, its acceleration was phenomenal: a 0-60mph time of under 4.4 seconds and 0-100mph in only 10.7 seconds were possible. Using competition springing to lower its ride-height by 50mm (while still maintaining the roll-axis of the car relative to the ground), the racecar was extensively track tested to optimize fine-tuned racecar dynamics. content: In practice, the biggest changes to the 'Elise Series 2' were without doubt to the overall appearance, styled by Steve Crijns under the supervision of Lotus Design Chief Russell Carr. Steve Crijns commented, "We wanted to create a shape that would reflect an incredible driving experience. The car has to look a hell of a lot more exciting than your everyday two-seater Cabrio. But we also wanted to be honest and not have any features just for stylistic effect." "We started by shrink-wrapping the bodywork around the mechanical components," Crijns continued, "Very early in the design phase, the full-size clay model went to the wind-tunnel where the rear spoiler and rear diffuser were created to optimize downforce without causing drag." A new rear diffuser in composite material augmented the regular Elise alloy panel flat under-floor sections and, in conjunction with the Elise S2's increased length, was more effective. Some motoring experts may have felt that the Elise went soft in its second edition, but they were no doubt deceived by the enhanced practicality: bigger boot, larger doorway access, and an options list that took in carpets, radio, and, by 2002, even air-conditioning. Lotus engineers managed the apparently impossible.

Some motoring experts may have felt that the Elise went soft in its second edition, but they were no doubt deceived by the enhanced practicality: bigger boot, larger doorway access, and an options list that took in carpets, radio, and by 2002, even air-conditioning. Lotus engineers managed the apparently impossible feat of stiffening up the chassis while simultaneously making the responses on the ragged edge a lot safer for an increased percentage of customers. Critical paths to such unlikely progress were the bespoke Bridgestone tyres and the installation of Bilstein high pressure damping instead of the Konis previously used. Forged steel hub-carriers replaced the original extruded aluminium ones and were accompanied by new wishbones, bushes, and mounting points for the aforementioned dampers. Both front and rear track was increased, as were the camber settings at the rear, while the chassis ride-height was lowered. The other tangible customer benefit of the S2 Elise was a far higher level of exterior finish brought about by the use of a new process for manufacturing the all-new composite body panels. A complete change of design philosophy led to a closed mould system that gave stronger, lighter panels, with a much improved finish.

Still with its Rover PG1-based gearbox, the ratios, including the 4.2:1 final drive, were those used throughout the production of the first Elise 111S and subsequently employed by the Exige and the 340R. Official performance figures were pretty close to the original, but occasionally independent magazine testers struggled to dip below 6 seconds for 0-60 mph. This was possibly due to the small rise in curb weight. Fuel consumption was practically unaltered, while emission performance was improved such that the Elise was now placed in the cheaper British Government tax brackets and conformed with Euro 3 emission levels. Autocar summarized the Series 2 Elise succinctly when they wrote: "Does the impossible – betters the original Elise. Ride handling and engine are improved on a car we thought was untouchable." The new car certainly came with a new, more immediate surge of power and was the best electronically managed Elise until the new 111S came along. With a taut chassis, rigid Eibach springs, and stout Bilsteins, the S2 Elise certainly responded well to the drivers' commands and, on turn-in to a corner, could even be considered superior to some single-seat racers. The same exhilarating abilities and reassuring consistency were present.

In 2002, after many aborted attempts and premature media predictions of its demise, it really was time for farewell to the Esprit. As the Sport 350 drew to the end of its 2001 run, Lotus earnestly sought suppliers for yet another small scale batch of components to ease just 82 Esprit 'Final Editions', all built to American specification, off the assembly lines at Hethel.
