Each car was subject to enhanced quality control checks, examined in detail within a brightly lit inspection bay. Any problems were then rectified by a specialist finishing crew wearing special protective clothing. The final testing stage before each of the last Esprits was shipped proved its considerable capabilities on the Lotus test track.

The Final Edition Esprit continued to use the double wishbone, coil-spring/telescopic damper set up at the front and the upper/lower transverse link with box-section radius arm configuration at the rear. The spring/damper units were rated to deliver an even more sporting bias (but not as extreme as for the Sport 350), while retaining the standard ride.

The spring/damper units were rated to deliver an even more sporting bias, but not as extreme as for the Sport 350, while retaining the standard ride height of the car. Bilstein dampers had stiffened settings, equipped with adjustable threaded spring platforms offering easier ride height adjustment. The Eibach conical road springs, fitted at both front and rear, were uprated and combined with the dampers to give the last Esprits a distinct feedback. Suspension geometry remained unchanged, set at the mid-laden ride height of 170mm front and 163mm rear.

The power output of the twin-turbocharged V8 remained at 350bhp and was balanced by the stopping power of the four ventilated disc brakes which had the Kelsey-Hayes 430, 3-channel ABS fitted as standard. 

Interior features included aluminium accents that added flair to 'The Final Edition'. The leather gearlever gaiter, secured at its base by an aluminium bezel, was accompanied by a new, shorter gear lever knob finished in brushed aluminium and topped with a Lotus badge. The aluminium trim on the instrument cluster further heightened the interior's high tech appearance.

The leather-trimmed seating of 'The Final Edition' seats featured a distinctive new stitch pattern. Perhaps the most critical component was the Renault-sourced rear transaxle gearbox and associated driveshafts. content: The 2003 Sport Elise 135R is a special edition car that was launched at dealerships around the UK on the 1st of May 2003. It was only available to UK customers and was denoted by the Lotus Sport chassis plate fixed into the passenger footwell. Despite its exhilarating performance, the 135R managed to remain a very usable road car for everyday use, offering the driver the best of both worlds. The power output of 135bhp was achieved by modifying the ports of the cylinder head to improve gas flow, fuel mixture, and maximize cylinder capacity. The standard Elise intake manifold was replaced by a cast alloy version as used on the 111S. Alongside a reprogrammed ECU, these modifications further improved the Elise's 'engine breathing,' allowing the driver to fully explore maximum engine revs in all gears, and increasing driver enjoyment, especially during events such as the fast-growing track-day scene. Developed by Lotus Sport and Performance in conjunction with the Lotus Ride and Handling team, the Lotus Sport Elise 135R was designed to provide ultimate performance both on and off the track. Engine, suspension, wheel, and tyre upgrades all contribute to the car's capabilities.

Unpowered soapboxes had been racing down the famous hillclimb course at the Goodwood Festival of Speed since 2000, and an entry in the 2002 event was an ideal opportunity for graduates to represent Lotus in the competition. The first Lotus soapbox, designated as the Type 119, was entered in the open-topped 'roadster' class, rather than the more challenging closed-cockpit 'streamliner' class. Led by David Stacey, the team was granted access to the extensive facilities at Lotus’ Hethel site, but it could only work outside working hours and within the regulations’ budget. Support would eventually be required from over 150 Lotus employees, from metalwork fabricators to CAD modellers, from Lotus Design stylists to buyers. The team also brought in sponsors to supply hi-tech materials in return for logo placement on the vehicle.

Towards the end of 2001, the Group Lotus board gave approval for a team of young engineers on the company’s Graduate Scheme to enter the prestigious 'Goodwood Gravity Racing Club Soapbox Challenge', paving the way for what was to become an annual graduate project. To ensure a super smooth aerodynamic profile, the advanced carbon composite monocoque chassis was designed using the latest Computer-Aided Engineering (CAE) software, while ultra-lightweight components were used to minimize the overall weight. The soapbox's performance was impressive, with a top speed of 60 mph and an acceleration of 0 to 60 mph in just 4.2 seconds. The Type 119 showcased not only the engineering prowess of the graduates but also the innovative spirit of Lotus.

To ensure a super smooth aerodynamic profile, the advanced carbon composite monocoque chassis was designed using the latest Computer-Aided Engineering (CAE) software, while ultra-low-resistance bearings ensured that the 18.5-inch wheels spun as freely as possible. The Type 119's neatest trick, though, was its clever Active Mass Distribution (AMD) system that shifted lead ballast laterally to the side of the soapbox on the inside of the corner. This optimized the weight distribution to produce more grip, resulting in faster cornering. It was ingenious, and pilot Paul Adams claimed that at high speed he could gently steer the soapbox using only the AMD. After the nine-month program, glory eluded the Type 119 at Goodwood 2002. Over the two runs, Adams piloted the Type 119 to second in class and third overall behind BMW's Project Rolls Royce roadster and McLaren's streamliner. It was, however, a gallant debut in a field of 26 competitors. The following year, five newly employed graduates took up the Goodwood challenge with the Type 119B roadster. James Setter led the team and believed victory would result from achieving the minimum possible aerodynamic and rolling resistance, so a brand new monocoque chassis design was penned. Lotus Sport, the motor sport division of Lotus Cars Ltd., developed these two higher performance versions of the 2006 Model Year Lotus Exige, designated the Lotus Exige Cup 190 and the Lotus Exige Cup 240, for track (and road) use straight out of the box. Constructed around the basic ’06 Exige, both cars were completely track ready.

The 2-Eleven used a unique, stronger, and stiffer high-sided variant of the Elise lightweight chassis, now known as the Lotus Small Platform Chassis, featuring epoxy-bonded aluminum alloy extrusions with modified Exige S-based running gear. Additional chassis safety features included an FIA-compliant 6-point rollover structure with integral harness mounts and a lightweight galvanized steel rear subframe incorporating a further crushable structure. The front tires were 195/50R16, and the rear tires were 225/45. The brake system deployed 288mm cast iron cross-drilled and ventilated discs, upgraded Pagid RS14 sports brake pads fitted to aluminum alloy AP Racing 2-piston at the front and Brembo single sliding piston at the rear. The fully independent suspension utilized unequal length wishbones and Öhlins 2-way adjustable dampers.

The new Lotus Europa S, a Grand Touring (GT) inspired two-seater, provided Lotus customers with significantly enhanced levels of touring and cruising capability. With increased levels of both practicality and refinement in comparison to the simplicity of the Elise and Exige models, Lotus created a "More Luxury" driving experience. Based on the Lotus Small Platform chassis, the Europa S was not a derivative of the Elise or the Exige and, following a two-year plus development program, was allocated a new Lotus Type number of 121. Seen by project manager Tony Shute as a slightly larger and more comfortable almost-GT-style car but still extreme, the Europa was built to include creature comforts such as satellite navigation and leather trim. The Europa S still followed the core Lotus philosophy of performance through lightweight, which enabled this refined and high-performing GT car to weigh in at just 995 kg. This low weight was obtained through the clever use of advanced and high-tech materials, including the now familiar extruded and bonded aluminum chassis, composite body panels, and a very advanced composite energy-absorbing front crash structure. As all Elise drivers know, extricating yourself from an Elise/Exige with the roof on can be a challenge.

content: Lotus Engineering's core competencies include lightweight architectures, efficient performance, electrical and electronics integration, and driving dynamics. The technology demonstrator represents an encapsulation of the advanced technologies that Lotus Engineering continues to develop in an effort to overcome the current environmental challenges facing the automotive industry. It showcases the future direction that the sector is taking and why Lotus Engineering is perfectly placed to lead the technological development in this area. For the Evora 414E Hybrid, Lotus Engineering developed a highly efficient, high-performance drivetrain system consisting of twin motors each limited to providing 152 kW (204 bhp) of power and 295 lb-ft of torque to each wheel via independent, single-speed, reduction transmissions integrated into a single housing, enabling torque vectoring dynamic control of the vehicle. The vehicle energy storage system was made up of the latest Lithium Polymer battery chemistry, providing 17 kWh energy storage capacity. The battery pack was optimized for energy density, efficiency, and high power demand, with over 100 kW discharge capability. The Lotus Range Extender engine provided 35 kW (47 bhp) of power at 3,500 rpm via the integrated electrical generator and featured an innovative architecture comprising an aluminum monoblock construction, integrating the cylinder block, cylinder head, and exhaust manifold in one casting.

Efficiency and high power demand, with over 100 kW discharge capability, were key features of the Lotus Range Extender engine. The engine provided 35 kW (47 bhp) of power at 3,500 rpm via the integrated electrical generator. It featured an innovative architecture with an aluminium monoblock construction, integrating the cylinder block, cylinder head, and exhaust manifold in one casting. This resulted in reduced engine mass, assembly costs, package size, and improved emissions and engine durability. The engine used an optimized two-valve, port-fuel injection combustion system to reduce cost and mass and could be operated on alcohol-based fuels and/or gasoline. 

The generator converted mechanical energy to electrical energy to replenish the battery pack charge and provide additional vehicle range in a small, lightweight package. It was also used as a motor to start the range extender engine. The low mass of the range extender unit, at just 85 kg, and its compact package made it ideal for the series hybrid drivetrain in the Evora 414E. For everyday commuting journeys, up to 35 miles could be travelled using battery power. The battery could be charged overnight using a conventional domestic mains supply through a socket concealed by the rear number plate, allowing the vehicle to operate with zero tailpipe emissions. For longer journeys exceeding the battery range, the range extender engine would kick in, ensuring a seamless driving experience.

The team was the second of three new Formula 1 teams for the 2010 season. Lotus Racing unveiled the T127 (Type 127) Grand Prix contender at London’s Royal Horticultural Halls in mid-February. The brainchild of Tony Fernandes, together with fellow shareholders Kamarudin Meranun and SM Nasarudin, they led a consortium of Malaysian business interests to join forces to provide initial funding for the team under the parent company 1Malaysia Racing Team. The new team had ties with the Lotus Cars brand through one of the team’s financial backers, Proton, who at the time owned the Lotus brand. The 2010 Model Year range from Lotus was announced at the Geneva Motorshow in March of 2010. While the Exige range remained essentially unchanged, revisions to the base model Elise (the 'S' was dropped off the base model's name – it was now just a Lotus Elise) were more than simply cosmetic. The base model now had a smaller 1.6-litre Toyota-sourced engine, to replace the last generation's 1.8-litre unit, but the basic chassis, brakes, and dimensions essentially remained unchanged.

The overall styling on what is now regarded as a 'Series 3' Elise was subtly tweaked, and while the headlights were the stand-out change, revisions to the new-look Elise also included: a revised front body design with enlarged oil cooler intake ducts and chin spoilers; restyled radiator outlet ducts; a one-piece lift-out access cover to the engine; aluminum mesh grilles; a separate rear transom panel without faux end grilles; a new rear diffuser; new headlamp units incorporating LED turn lamps and LED daytime running lamps; and new 12-spoke lightweight alloy cast road-wheels, or new 5-'Y' spoke forged wheels of 5.5x16-inch and 7.5x17-inch dimensions.

The Elise S model of the previous year was replaced with a new model.

content: Anyone under the misapprehension that Lotus might be moving away from 'performance through lightweight' philosophy, only needed to take a ride in the new Elise Club Racer announced in February of 2011, to know that this was definitely not the case. The engineers at Lotus put the lightest car of their current range on a diet, and managed to shed a further 24 kg. So how did they manage to make one of the lightest models on the market even lighter? The engineers behind the Elise Club Racer took a stripped-to-the-bare-bone approach, emphasized by the body-colored seats, but materialized in many other ways, such as the motorsport-derived lightweight battery and the deletion of certain standard factory-fitted components such as carpets, radio, and speakers, passenger footrest, central locking, mud flaps, and noise insulation. Attention to even the smallest of details ensured that Lotus' passion for performance through lightweight was translated throughout the car. For the first time ever, an Elise variant came complete with a Sport setting for the DPM (Dynamic Performance Management), allowing even the less experienced sports car drivers to feel at the top of their game, while the ability to switch it off completely pleased the more established drivers.

When we mentioned to the design team and some of our contractors that we were going to go to Le Mans, they didn't think it would have 2011 in the date; they were looking at 2012! But everything that Lotus is doing at the moment is aggressive timing, and we're delivering everything that we say we're going to do," Lotus Motorsport Product Manager Gavan Kershaw stated. At first glance, the new GTE-spec Evora racecar may have seemed to have a similar appearance to the Evora GT4, which debuted in 2010, but as Kershaw explained, "roughly 85 percent of the car is brand-new, with the production chassis remaining one of the only key components that's been carried over." With their Cosworth-tuned engines bored out from 3.5 to 4.0 litres and all-new bodywork as well as larger wheels and uprights, the Nicola Scimeca-designed Evora GTE was almost 120lb heavier than the GT4 model, yet was still considered a lightweight in the GTE racing category. Despite the engineering challenges, the program remained relatively on schedule, with the first Evora GTE hitting the track in early April and completing around 1,000 kilometers of testing.

Despite the engineering challenges, the program remained relatively on schedule, with the first Evora GTE hitting the track in early April and completing around 1,000 miles of testing. A further 700 miles were logged at the car's first public appearance, the one-day Le Mans test. Under the careful direction of Team Manager Jan Kalmar, the JetAlliance team fielded two cars in the 2011 Le Mans 24-hour race and, having qualified well in the new GTE class, both cars ran strongly. The number 64 car of Martin Rich, John Hartshorne, and Oskar Slinger retired on lap 127 when a broken wheel left the car stranded on track. Remarkably though, the number 65 car of Johnny Mowlem, James Rossiter, and Jonathan Hirschi lasted the full 24 hours and was classified 22nd overall. An excellent result given the short development time.

content: To celebrate the terrific result for the GTE racecar at that year's Le Mans 24-hour race, the road-going Evora GTE concept car was unveiled to the world for the first time on August 17th as part of the Lotus exhibit at the Monterey Jet Centre in California. Commenting on the Evora GTE road car, Group Lotus CEO Dany Bahar said: "To celebrate our successful return to Le Mans this year, we created the ultimate road car racer. Initially, we hoped to introduce this to the Asian market with our partners in China as a 'taste of Lotus'. However, the response was so great that we received 114 orders from China alone. This justified us looking into speeding up the process of bringing this car to other territories. We showed a concept at Pebble Beach and are showing this production intent car at Frankfurt. We will bring this car to Europe and the US. People get so excited when they see and especially hear it for the first time. It's a very special car and will appeal to a very special type of driver – and they won't be disappointed!"

On September 24th, 2010, it was announced that Lotus Racing, headed up by Tony Fernandes, had acquired the name rights of Team Lotus, marking what would eventually be an all too brief, official rebirth of Team Lotus in Formula 1. By 2012, however, the F1 team based out of Norfolk would be rebranded as Caterham F1. On October 5th, 2010, the team announced that they had agreed to a deal with Red Bull Technology for the supply of their seven-speed, semi-automatic gearbox and hydraulic systems for 2011. On November 5th, the team confirmed an engine partnership for the next two years with Renault, and on November 30th, the FIA released the entry list for the 2011 season in which the former Lotus Racing was listed under the name “Team Lotus.”

content: Hoop, in its place a 'blade'. The concept was essentially the same as that employed on the Mercedes MGP W01, removing the hoop and relocating the intakes for the 90-degree Renault V8 engine to lower on the engine cover, while fulfilling the requirement for a rollover structure with a solid central structure (or blade). It was said that this approach gave the all-important and much cleaner airflow to the rear wing. After the MGP W01 version was fully revealed at the Spanish Grand Prix, queries were raised about the safety of the concept: would the blade dig into the ground in a rollover? The rule makers took heed, and the following appeared in the 2011 technical regulations: 15.2.4 The principal roll structure must have a minimum enclosed structural cross section of 10,000 mm², in vertical projection, across a horizontal plane 50 mm below its highest point. The area thus established must not exceed 200 mm in length or width and may not be less than 10,000 mm² below this point. Many took this as an outright ban on the blade concept, but Mike Gascoyne and his team thought differently, and the TL11 met the new regulation fully.

content: The 2011 season saw Team Lotus pull away in performance from fellow new teams HRT and Virgin, but fail to close in on the lower-ranking established teams. The two cars pretty much failed to make it out of Q1 at any race (Kovalainen did manage to make it through to Q2 in Spain and qualified 15th). A clutch of 13th place finishes was the best that drivers Trulli and Kovalainen (Karun Chandhock substituted for Trulli in Germany) could muster over the course of the year, but that was enough to secure 10th in the championship (again) and pull in a share of the F1 money that the team badly needed to survive for another year in the high-dollar world of F1.

With the new engine and improved throttle response, the Elise S delivered instant acceleration and, with even more torque accessible from low in the rev range, gave an even more exhilarating and lively drive experience than any previous Elise. The more efficient engine resulted in lower fuel consumption: Urban 27.3 mpg, Extra Urban 47.6 mpg, Combined 37.5 mpg, and a far lower CO2 emissions of 175g/km than the outgoing Elise SC. The all-alloy, charge-cooled, 1.8-litre DOHC 4-cylinder, dual VVT-i, 16-valve engine was fitted with the latest Magnuson R900 supercharger, utilizing Eaton TV technology, and gave the Elise S an incredible-for-its-engine-size 0-60 mph time of just 4.5 seconds. Mated to the EC60 6-speed gearbox, on which a new 'low-friction' selector cable system gave a much smoother shift, 100 mph could be attained in 11.2 seconds, before the maximum of 145 mph was reached.

Selecting Sport mode and Lotus DPM (Dynamic Performance Management) added to the Elise's handling by offering extra stability, on the rare occasions that the exceptionally high levels of grip were exceeded. A selectable Sport mode took DPM one step further, allowing the driver to safely explore the limits further still. Performance dynamics were of course matched both aesthetically and aerodynamically.

At the start of the season, the E20 began the quest for victory as perhaps the fastest car of all, on race pace for sure, but a lack of one-lap qualifying pace often left it too far down the grid to be able to win. The team was also involved in an early season protest over the use of a “radical” rear wing concept on Mercedes AMG’s Mercedes F1 W03, later dubbed the ‘F-Duct rear wing’ or ‘Double DRS’. The dispute was not settled until the third race in China when the stewards unanimously rejected their formal protest and Lotus subsequently confirmed they would not appeal against the decision.

Power for the E20 came from a 2.4-litre, 90-degree V8 Renault RS27-2012 unit coupled to the 7-speed, Lotus F1 Team/X-Trac gearbox and AP Racing clutch. The engine’s electronics system came from Magneti Marelli, managed by the now standardised across all the teams, McLaren Electronics Systems ECU. Spark plugs were of the NGK variety, and fuel and oil were supplied by sponsor (or should we say ‘Partner’) Total. The front suspension featured carbon-fibre double wishbones with pull-rod operated inboard torsion-bar dampers. The rear end featured a similar wishbone set-up.

Wheels were from OZ and, of course, shod with the regular Formula 1 contracted supplier Pirelli 'P-Zero' tires. AP Racing again supplied the brake hardware, while pads and discs came from Hitco.

On track, the E20’s strengths were clearly great driveability and the fact that it was easy on its tires, something probably connected to the fact it appeared to be a much softer riding car than most of its rivals. In 2012, Lotus ventured into a new frontier with the Evora GX as their entry into the Grand-Am Rolex Sports Car Series. Following their involvement with Formula 1, IndyCar, and Le Mans, among others, Lotus came to the series at the end of 2012 with a new version of the Evora racecar. The Evora GX was based loosely on the Evora GTC racer that had evolved from the 2011 Enduro model, which had been crowned 2012 MSA British Endurance Champion in the regular GT class with the Bullrun Team. The race-spec Evora GX was customized specifically for the rigors of Grand-Am racing. Among the notable new features were carbon-fibre doors, a roof and engine cover, plexiglass windows, and tinted headlights, which all helped to reduce weight to around 2,535 pounds. This was only an impressive 22 pounds heavier than the lithe Evora GTC, despite having a much thicker US-spec roll cage. The car also came with a new race-spec aero kit with new parts being fitted, including a new front splitter and bumper, a series-required rear wing, and new wider wheels.

"With the new R-GT rules in rallying, it's a very interesting time for us to return to the sport. Naturally, our approach this time around will be different to when we won the championship three decades ago, but I think our philosophy is definitely the same: we want to compete and ultimately we want to win."

In November of 2013, Lotus Motorsport announced the latest addition to its racing portfolio: the Lotus Elise S Cup R. Following the success of the Exige V6 Cup and its hardcore sibling, the Exige V6 Cup R, the Lotus Elise S was adorned with the Lotus Motorsport magic to present a track-only edition, the Elise S Cup R. Evolving from the 1.6-litre Elise platform, this was the first time the supercharged mid-mounted, transverse, 1.8-litre 2ZR-FE engine from the Elise S had been used in a Cup variant. In 2015, Formula 1 saw the introduction of the Lotus E23. On 5 July 2014, Lotus F1 announced that the E23 car under development for the 2015 season would be switching to Mercedes power. This change ended the team’s association with Renault, but drivers Romain Grosjean and Pastor Maldonado remained with the team. The first images of the E23 were released to the press on January 26th, and the first car was fired up at the Lotus F1 Team base in Enstone in the evening of Saturday, 31st January. The car was immediately packed and left for pre-season testing at Jerez. Although other teams started running on 1 February, Lotus arrived late and managed to debut their car on track on 2 February, ahead of the team’s expectations.

One of the most noticeable features of the E23 was the roll hoop duct arrangement. Alongside and slightly below the conventional inlet for combustion air, there were two extra ducts. Initially, the purpose of these was unclear to observers, but it soon became apparent that they fed air to a heat exchanger mounted toward the rear of the Mercedes power unit. A fourth, much smaller duct below the main inlet area sat directly behind the driver's helmet.

Set to go on sale in Europe in December of 2015, the Lotus Elise Sport and Elise Sport 220 marked a return to the iconic 'Sport' naming designation, previously used on the Esprit. With it, the Lotus Elise package became lighter and even more performance-focused. Twenty years before, the Lotus Elise revolutionized the sports car world, setting the benchmark for handling, purity of the driving experience, lightweight, and efficiency. Its pioneering and advanced bonded aluminum chassis was a market-leading technological innovation at the time and over the years has improved and evolved, remaining core to the Elise's exceptional performance to this day.

Both the new Elise Sport and Elise Sport 220 benefitted from a significant weight reduction of 10kg, a result of the continued central design philosophy of Lotus – 'lighter, faster' and the perpetual quest to reduce weight of all constituent parts and in some cases remove unnecessary parts altogether. Weighing just 866kg, the Elise Sport set a benchmark that both enthusiasts and newcomers to the brand found easy to fall in love with. Lightweight, efficient, and completely pure in its driving experience, its handling and quickness in road holding remained, as ever, the envy of all.

The 'Road' version, with a dry weight of 925 kg and a maximum power of 410 bhp, reached 60 mph in 3.3 seconds before attaining a top speed of 174 mph. Costing £3,000 less than the GT410 Sport, it truly delivered exceptional value for money. The Evora GT410 features a Type 122 engine. As production of the Evija all-electric hypercar commences, Lotus announced the opening of a new manufacturing facility in Norwich as well as an advanced technology centre in Warwickshire.

By 2019, there were certainly plenty of different versions of Norfolk's premier GT car around. Following the Evora's 2015 facelift, there had been the 400, the 400 Hethel Edition, the Sport 410, the GT430, and the GT430 Sport. However, by the start of 2020, your only option in Europe at least was the 2019 model year GT410 Sport. In the four years to the end of 2019, the Evora range had seen just under 2,000 cars emerge from the Hethel factory. New for 2020 was the Evora GT410. Rather than a whole new Evora, the new model was, for all intents and purposes, a new trim level, but one that made perfect sense. Lotus Cars were keen to point out that it was designed to be a more usable daily driver than the GT410 Sport.

“Over the past three to four years, we’ve been extremely focused on the lightest possible cars, the highest power, extracting real lap times out of them all,” said Gavan Kershaw at Lotus. “We’d moved away from plushness, and then, when Phil Popham joined as our new boss, he had an Evora as his personal car and said ‘it’s amazing, but I’m doing quite a lot of miles in it, and I want it to be more comfortable and more usable.’”

Lotus Design Director Russell Carr commented: "The Evija is beyond anything Lotus has ever done... beyond anything I've ever done. We have created something beautiful, something new, dramatic and unique." The Evija was set to be the most powerful and dynamically accomplished road car in the history of Lotus, and set a new standard for Lotus driving performance. It was the first all-electric British hypercar and the first Lotus with an electrified powertrain, as well as the first new model since Geely took control of Lotus in 2017.

At first known only by its Lotus Type number – Type 130 – the car was christened the Lotus Evija (pronounced 'E-vi-ya'). As a name, it is derived from variations of Eve, and means 'the first in existence' or 'the living one'. It is highly appropriate; Lotus has an unquestionable reputation for its pioneering approach in both automotive and motorsport. The Evija was the first Lotus road car to feature a one-piece carbon-fibre monocoque chassis.

Engineered for precise and sustained performance, the Evija had five driving modes – Range, City, Tour, Sport, and Track – and could rush from 0-62 mph (0-100 km/h) in under three seconds and accelerate to a top speed of more than 200 mph (0-320 km/h).

The most striking element of the Lotus Evija was its exterior. From every angle, the full carbon-fibre bodywork appeared shrink-wrapped over the mechanical components. Unquestionably, the most dramatic element of the exterior was the Venturi tunnel that pierced each rear quarter. Inspired by Le Mans race cars, they optimized airflow by directing it through the bodyshell. This design concept, known as 'porosity', aided the delivery of high-energy airflow to the rear of the car. This, in turn, counteracted the low pressure behind the car to reduce drag. Designed in three sections, the larger central area provided air to cool the battery pack – mid-mounted behind the two seats – while the air channeled through the two smaller outer sections cools the front e-axle. When asked how the Evija's sophisticated aerodynamics compared to more regular sports cars, Richard Hill, the highly experienced senior engineer who has guided this critical element of the car's design, commented: "It's like comparing a fighter jet to a child's kite." He further explained, "It's about keeping the airflow low and flat at the front and guiding it through the body to emerge high at the rear. Put simply, it transforms the whole car into an inverted wing to produce that all-important dynamic downforce. As the first all-electric hypercar from a British car maker, the launch of the Evija saw Lotus deliver an opportunity for new and exciting expansion of the sector. Increasing consumer awareness and demand for the astonishing performance available through EV powertrains meant new growth and new skills, and Lotus intended to be a key player in that revolution.
The Evija is a true Lotus in every sense - it has been developed with an unwavering passion to push boundaries and to explore new ways of thinking. Lotus Cars, CEO.

content: The first stage of the program to develop two Evora GT4 racecars gained approval in November 2019, and development work began in April 2020. Working with the Evora GT4 chassis platform from the successful 2017 and 2018 seasons, the long-term intention for the project was always to underpin the car with the yet to be announced and still top secret Emira suspension, powertrain, and gearbox. The basic concept of the 2020 Evora GT Racecar was as a development project for the also yet to be announced Emira GT4 project, which would be given the same 131 Type number as the Emira ahead of the soon to be announced Type 132 Lifestyle Vehicle. Commenting on the prospect of seeing a Type 129 on the track, the CEO of Lotus Cars at the time, Phil Popham, said: "Lotus as a brand was born from the thrill of competition, and this new Evora racecar will continue that legacy while opening a new chapter in our racing experience. All of our road cars retain motorsport within their DNA, and almost every road car in the company’s history has raced successfully at some point. It’s the philosophy that Colin Chapman founded Lotus on."

In 2019, Australia was the sixth largest market globally for Lotus and to mark that success, the company produced six examples of a highly exclusive limited run 'Bathurst Edition' car. Paying homage to the circuit and Lotus' pedigree in motorsport on the continent, the limited-run, Australia-only cars enjoyed a host of eye-catching upgrades. These included black forged alloy wheels (16-inch front and 17-inch rear), a special numbered build-plate, distinctive red wing mounts, and bespoke 'Bathurst Cup 250' decals that complemented the Monaco White paint that Lotus claimed hadn't been used on a production Lotus since the Esprit used in the Bond film "The Spy Who Loved Me." With more than 45,000 fans attending the Bathurst 12-Hour race that weekend, Lotus took its place trackside for the three-day event. There it offered a unique opportunity to more than 150 enthusiastic Lotus owners, who witnessed some of the world's finest drivers tackle the challenging Mount Panorama circuit. Many owners drove the track in their own Lotus cars, taking advantage of an on-site mentoring program that allowed them to get the most out of the experience. They were also able to sign up for hot laps with professional Lotus drivers.

content: Emira GT4 Racecar: Following the July launch of the Lotus Emira and its dynamic debut at the Goodwood Festival of Speed, Lotus was fully committed to writing a successful new chapter in the story of Lotus in the motorsport arena. The Hethel-based development team focused on precision engineering to deliver outstanding dynamics and high-speed stability. Suspension both front and rear saw double wishbones supported by Ohlins coil-over dampers and an anti-roll bar. The Alcon discs and calipers brake system was fitted with a full Bosch Motorsport ABS system. Each customer car would be a homologated performance machine, hand-built with lightweight motorsport components and equipment to meet the latest safety regulations including a Motec-supplied dashboard with full data-logging and a bespoke motorsport loom.
